Re: License #: CP630201334
Dear Mr. Scheuer:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/21/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
FOM POLICY 722 – 06B Family Team Meeting: Types and Timeframes
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames
as outlined…Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30
days prior to the service plan due date.
2 of 6 open foster care case files did not meet FTM requirements.
FOM POLICY 722. 08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
SIGNATURES
2

Once completed and approved, the caseworker
must obtain signatures from the following
individuals, as applicable:
Caseworker, Supervisor, second line
supervisor, when siblings in care are
place apart, Parents who are a member of a
participating household. Youth ages 14 and
older. Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers
must check yes or no for the following when
signing the treatment plan: I have participated
in the Development of the Case Service Plan
and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
5 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed (11 of 21 PATPS) contained
PATP signatures that were not obtained timely and/or the boxes were not
checked indicating participation of the service plans.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during
this period under review.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator (CA) reported to improve the outcome for their youth in
care. Their agency is partnering with a private agency to pilot the kinship
connections program. He stated this program has a focus on kinship care and
3

supportive services for kinship caregivers. Implementation of this program has
significantly impacted both operational and programmatic aspects of the child
welfare system for those children who must be placed in foster care.
The CA reported staff turnover in 2023 continued to be an ongoing challenge for
compliance. He said in order to maintain caseload compliance and continuity of
service delivery, it is critical to have new hires available to fill vacancies. He
reported that in situations where staff departure is unexpected, it takes an
extended amount of time to have a new staff hired and trained for the vacant
position. He reported another struggle their agency faced is insufficient foster and
relative homes to meet the increasing needs of the children entering foster care
along with a lack of family support and agency resources to provide to caregivers.
The CA reported that on a positive note, all staff have received ongoing direction
and training on licensing rules, policy and ISEP commitments on an ongoing
basis. He said Oakland County conducts monthly meetings with foster care
supervisors and staff regarding Key Performance Indicators and any applicable
policy issues. He said supervisors also participate in weekly Book of Business
meetings with staff.
Financial Overview
A financial audit was not required, this licensee is an MDHHS office.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff on site. Staff reported feeling supported
by the agency and supervisors are always available. Staff reported their
coworkers assist them if needed and that they all communicate with one another
on a consistent basis. Staff reported the only concern they have would be if the
agency would hire more workers with flexible hours to assist with parenting time.
Staff reported this is one of their greatest needs.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has sufficient office space and equipment to perform the job functions.
The case files & CHRI records are stored in locked cabinets to prevent
unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency had one safety alert:
Concern:
The caregivers have a spa/hot tub with a cover that cannot be locked when the tub
is not in use. The basement does not have a smoke detector.
Resolution:
The licensing worker went to the home on 12/12/2023 and verified that the
caregivers installed locks on the hot tub that is operable. The caregivers also have a
flotation rescue ring that was observed by the licensing worker. The smoke detector
4

was installed in the basement, tested and in working order. Photos verification of all
items was provided.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
